chart.title: Excess mortality: Deaths from all causes compared to average over previous years
chart.subtitle: Percentage difference between the reported weekly or monthly deaths in 2020–2024 and the average deaths in the same period in 2015–2019.
chart.note: The reported number of deaths might not count all deaths that occurred due to incomplete coverage and delays in reporting.
chart.citation: Human Mortality Database (2024); World Mortality Dataset (2024); Karlinsky and Kobak (2021)

p_avg_all_ages.titleShort: Excess mortality P-scores, 5-year average baseline, all ages
p_avg_all_ages.titleLong: Excess mortality P-scores, 5-year average baseline, all ages
p_avg_all_ages.descriptionShort: P-scores using 5-year average baseline for all ages.
descriptionKey: Excess deaths is estimated as _Excess deaths = Number of reported deaths - Number of expected deaths_. Excess mortality goes beyond confirmed COVID-19 fatalities by capturing all deaths above a projected baseline, including indirect deaths from pandemic-related disruptions.
All-cause mortality data is from the Human Mortality Database (HMD) Short-term Mortality Fluctuations project and the World Mortality Dataset (WMD). Both sources are updated weekly.
We use the baseline estimates by [Ariel Karlinsky and Dmitry Kobak (2021)](https://elifesciences.org/articles/69336) as part of their World Mortality Dataset (WMD).

We do not use the data from some countries in WMD because they fail to meet the following data quality criteria: 1) at least three years of historical data; and 2) data published either weekly or monthly. The full list of excluded countries and reasons for exclusion can be found in [this spreadsheet](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1JPMtzsx-smO3_K4ReK_HMeuVLEzVZ71qHghSuAfG788/edit?usp=sharing).
p_avg_all_ages.citationShort: Human Mortality Database (2025); World Mortality Database (2024) – processed by Our World in Data
p_avg_all_ages.citationLong: Human Mortality Database (2025); World Mortality Database (2024) – processed by Our World in Data. “Excess mortality P-scores, 5-year average baseline, all ages” [dataset].
